author: John Romano
title: Cardano Marketplace
description:
Blockchain solutions for IBO's are extremely hard to find and understand.

A dev and freelance blockchain-focused platform doesn't exist.

assessments.note: It is not clear this proposal meets the challenge of the dev ecosystem

For this project to add significant value relies on achieving a very large scale. I don't think Cardano is mature enough at this point  to attract that kind of interest. Developing such a platform could help developers in the future, though, so I do see some value.  However the proposal is too ambitious and costly at this stage, in my opinion. A proposal with more modest costs  would be better matched to the expected immediate impact.  In fact, the goals for success are only numbers of listings or sales on the platform. Since the platform already exists, it seems like a small marketing team could achieve these goals without investing in an office etc. Once Cardano is more developed, this industry-friendly appearance will be more important, but that could come in later funding rounds.
This doesn't necessarily grow the number of devs, only helps meet the demand with the offer
There is no clarity on how this proposal will address the challenge or how it will bring improvements to developers. The absence of reasonable metrics and KPIs compromises the impact assessment.

The COVID environment has opened up a large number of remote positions, even in core business models. This phenomenon has also increased the freelancing model for getting the job done. Therefore this Cardano market is addressing a core requirement.
Proposers are asking for funds for something they have already built. Thus it will be done. Though given its already done, why would Project Catalyst give it more money?

The proposer appears to have access to a qualified pool of developers although little specific details are given. The project website provided is functional and of high quality, which gives confidence. The proposer participated actively with the community during the refinement stage, but the proposal could be much more concise and organized. This makes me wonder how well defined and thought out the proposal is.  The proposal has a lot of cost overhead and moving parts, and I'm not convinced the proposer is qualified to execute such a complex initiative efficiently.
Implementation probability could be ok, but the asking amount is way too high for this kind of project

There are no details about the core team. How many people will be involved in this proposal? Who are the team members? it is extremely important that there are details about the team members so that we can evaluate their experience and qualification to conduct and implement this proposal.

The proposal describes a rationale for why blockchain technology is important for IBOs and DEFs, but there is a lot of generic and unrelated information to the proposal itself. I recommend more objectivity in describing the proposal and focus on the plan and how it will address the challenge.

The plan is not clear and is not structured. There is no roadmap, no details on the technical aspects of the proposal.

There is a budget breakdown, but the absence of a detailed plan makes it difficult to assess the feasibility of the budget.

Why will there be a cost with facilities? Today the vast majority of Catalyst projects operate remotely and there is no clarity as to the need for a physical location.

What is the purpose of allocating part of the resources in giveaways?

USD 7,500 is allocated for software licenses. What software will be used?

The budget mentions the development of an NFT auction model and there is no information on NFTs in the proposal plan.

My point is that without a plan that explains the proposal and its technical aspects in detail, it is impossible to judge the feasibility of the budget.

I recommend that the above points be addressed so that the proposal more clearly indicates its viability.

The proposal claims experience in development; however, the proposal has a huge scope, from development, blockchain integration, smart contract development, and most importantly, security audit. The proposal has not presented past accomplishments of the proposer or any of his team members.
The project is feasible. It is not clear how it addresses the challenge. this is a market place. How does it help developers focus on building successful apps?

The proposer offers goals at 3,6, and 12 months on which to gauge success. They are defined by a number of listings and completed orders. No specific technical goals are given.  The proposal looks like an ambitious startup and lists so many costs to make auditing difficult. The startup nature also suggests that funds will be allocated inefficiently.
Information is enough but I think anyone could make a system like this for way less funding

This proposal lacks a lot of information to indicate its auditability.

There are no details on the number of people in the core team and their qualifications / experience. There is no roadmap. There are no KPIs. The lack of a structured and technical plan makes it difficult to understand the budget and this compromises auditability.

The metrics of success (3, 6 and 12 months) are not clear, what would be completed orders?

I recommend that the proposer use the Catalyst documentation as a reference to prepare the proposal.

The proposal is clear on the aim and the process to be followed to complete the project. However, task analysis and who and how many are planned for forming the team or the size of the existing team is not clear in the proposal.

solution: "Cardano Marketplace is building a freelance exchange by connecting IBO's & DEF's across Cardano as a Multi-Vendor Marketplace."
experience: Core team-60+ years of combined computer science and product adoption exp. FSD, national product launch for fortune 100 companies, R&D.
